Graphical abstract The 3DOM FeCo/NC bifunctional catalyst, featuring a three-dimensional ordered macro-porous structure, demonstrates exceptional hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen reduction reaction activities due to markedly enhanced active site utilization and robust, heterogeneous interfacial coupling of CoFe/CoFe2O4 sites. Optimizing active sites and enhancing mass transfer capability are of paramount importance for the improvement of electrocatalyst activity. On this basis, CoFe2O4/CoFe nanoparticles (NPs) loaded N-doped carbon (NC) that featured with interconnected three-dimensional (3D) ordered porous hierarchies (3DOM FeCo/NC) are prepared, and its electrocatalytic activity is studied. Due to the open structure of 3D ordered macro-pores that greatly improves the mass transfer capacity of the catalytic process and enhances the utilization of active sites inside the catalyst, as well as the uniform distribution of Fe and Co bimetallic sites on the porous skeleton, 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibits superior bi-functional catalytic activities for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The overpotential of HER is lower than that of commercial Pt/C when performed at high current density (>235 mA cm−2) in 1.0 M KOH, and the half-wave potential (0.896 V) of ORR in 0.1 M KOH is also superior to that of 20% commercial Pt/C and most other similar catalysts. The effective utilization and synergistic effect of CoFe2O4 and CoFe hetero-metallic sites remarkably enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, 3DOM FeCo/NC is assembled as an air electrode in Zn-air battery, and exhibits satisfactory maximum power density, open-circuit voltage, and charge/discharge stability over benchmark Pt/C + IrO2. This work contributes new insights into the design of transition-metal-based multifunctional catalysts, and has great potential for energy conversion and storage. Keywords 3D ordered macro-pores Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) Hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) Oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) Zn-air battery 1 Introduction Developing green and renewable energy is highly desirable for addressing the issues brought by traditional fossil fuels. Generation, storage, and utilization are the three typical processes of energy circulation, all of which require high efficiency. Elaboration of high-performance electrocatalysts is an effective strategy to make utmost of renewable energy. For example, water splitting to produce hydrogen needs catalysts to reduce overpotentials both in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process; storing energy by metal-air batteries requires catalysts for OER and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR); and the utilization of fuel cells cannot be separated from excellent catalyst for ORR [1–3]. Because HER and ORR are critical cathodic reactions for energy production and conversion, it is necessary to develop efficient and stable bi-functional catalysts for guaranteeing the reactions proceeding in an expedient and reliable manner [4–12]. Hitherto, Pt-based materials are still the most reliable and widely employed catalyst due to their exceptional HER and ORR performance [13,14]. Nevertheless, the elevated cost, sporadic abundance, and constrained stability impede the development of such noble metal-based catalysts. Transition metal (TM)-based catalysts, given their substantial abundance, low cost, and distinctive synergistic effect, have been investigated as alternatives to Pt [15–18]. In particular, dual TMs-based catalysts have received special attention with regard to their easy tailorable geometrical and electronic surface structures [19]. According to the abundant available reports, Fe-Co dual-TMs have been demonstrated to be a promising avenue for the preparation of bi-functional catalysts for HER and ORR [8,20–22]. The synergistic effect of Fe and Co can optimize O2 adsorption and proton-electron transfer between oxygen intermediates, and provides more favorable reaction centers [23]. Loading Fe-Co dual-TMs nanoparticles (NPs) onto N-doped porous carbon is attractive for achieving high-efficient catalyst, because it well combines high-density active sites with fast electrons transfer. The spinel state oxides of Co and Fe, CoFe2O4, have been reported to be superior catalytic activators, but most spinel oxides are insulators or semiconductors with wide bandgaps, and their conductivity needs to be improved in order to give full effect to the electrocatalytic activity [24]. Loading the spinel oxides with conductive carbon or coupling them with conductive metals (e.g., FeCo alloys) is an effective way to enhance spinel-based electrocatalysts [25,26]. Metal/metal oxide heterostructures can modulate the binding strength between the catalyst and intermediates by strong electronic interactions at the interface. In particular, coupling to the metal increases the Fermi surface energy of the metal oxide, leading to a better-matched work function for binding to OH−, O2, and intermediates [27,28]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are optimal precursors for the preparation of conductive carbon TMs catalysts based on their unique porous structure [29,30]. In particular, zeolite imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) exhibit good doping capability and can yield N-doped carbons upon pyrolysis [12,31–33]. However, ZIF-derived materials are always featured with disordered micro-pores, which tend to impede mass transfer from electrolyte towards the internal active sites [34,35]. Therefore, expanding the pore size of MOFs and their derivatives to a wider range (meso-pores, macro-pores) to fully expose active sites and increase mass transfer ability is highly desired for enhancing catalytic activity [34,36]. Hard template method is an effective strategy for constructing materials with hierarchical ordered structures, and it has been widely explored for energy materials [37–40]. In particular, nanocasting-guided self-assembly method to introduce ordered macropores (>∼50 nm) into MOFs has been widely investigated in the recent years. Specifically, precursor solution is introduced into the interstices of ordered templates via capillary forces. Subsequently, effective nucleation reagents are employed to induce heterogeneous nucleation and confine the growth of MOF crystals within the interstices. Ultimately, the templates are removed, resulting in the formation of three-dimensional (3D) ordered macro-porous (3DOM) MOFs [35,41–52]. For example, Yao et al. constructed a tannic acid-functionalized MOF with 3DOM structure, which can be employed as a precursor for the subsequent synthesis of Co-loaded O/N co-doped carbon (H-3DOM-Co/ONC) with hydrophilic surface. The resulting material exhibited an ORR half-wave potential of 0.841 V [42]. Zhang et al. reported an atomically dispersed FeN4 site-anchored 3DOM N-doped carbon (3DOM Fe-N-C), which exhibited promising ORR activity in both acidic and alkaline media with half-wave potentials of 0.875 and 0.784 V, respectively [35]. In a recent publication, Wang et al. described a Ni-modified CoP electrocatalyst with ordered macro-pores rich in in-built meso-pores (OMS-Ni1-CoP). The HER overpotential was 119 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Meanwhile, excellent catalytic ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) activity was observed in alkaline electrolyte as well as in complex electrolyte of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic hydrolysate [43]. Notwithstanding a lot of progress has been made, combining morphology design with the synergistic effect of bi-metallics to enlarge specific surface area and modulate electronic structure for preparing more efficient multi-functional electrocatalyst still remains a challenge. In this work, an excellent bi-functional electrocatalyst for HER and ORR was prepared by loading CoFe2O4 and CoFe biphasic NPs on a 3D ordered macro-meso-micro-porous N-doped carbon (3DOM FeCo/NC) via hard template method and dual solvent-induced heterogeneous nucleation. Highly ordered polystyrene (PS) microsphere array was used as template, and ferric acetylacetonate encapsulated ZnCo-ZIF was in situ grown in the voids of the PS matrix. After template removal and subsequent pyrolysis, Fe and Co elements were transformed into CoFe2O4 and CoFe species, and anchored in the skeleton of N-doped carbon. PS microspheres, connection sites between PS, and MOF derivative skeleton determine the macro-, meso-, and micro-scale pores of the catalyst, respectively. This periodic open-structure offered large specific area and high-density active sites, simultaneously considerably enhancing the mass transfer in the catalytic process and making internal active NPs easily accessible by electrolyte. The as-prepared 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibited attractive HER activity and impressive ORR performance. Zn-air battery was further assembled to assess the ORR performance of 3DOM FeCo/NC in actual application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were purchased and used without any further treatments: cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.99%, Aladdin Co.), 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM, 98%, Aladdin Co.), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, A.R. Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. (SCRC)), Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) K30 (Mw 40000, Innochem), styrene (A.R. Macklin), potassium persulfate (K2S2O8, A.R. SCRC), iron acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3, 98%, Damas-beta), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, A.R. SCRC), ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O, 25%, SCRC), methanol (CH3OH, A.R. SCRC), potassium hydroxide (KOH, A.R. SCRC), and Nafion PFSA Polymer (5.0–5.4 wt%, DUPONT). 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of ordered PS template Uniform PS spheres were synthesized by emulsion polymerization [53]. 13 mL of styrene was mixed with 100 mL of ultrapure water (18 MΩ cm−2 @ 25 °C, 0.5 g PVP K30 dissolved) in a 250 mL triple-necked flask and N2 passed through for 15 min. The mixed solution was then stirred at 75 °C for 30 min in oil bath. To initiate the polymerization of styrene, ultrapure water (10 mL) in which potassium persulfate (KPS) (0.2 g) was dissolved was added. The reaction was performed at 75 °C for 24 h under N2 atmosphere. Finally, the milky emulsion was pump-filtered to obtain an ordered PS template. 2.2.2 Preparation of 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF 10 g of the PS template was immersed in methanol (20 mL) solution containing of Fe(acac)3 (1.207 g), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (3.672 g), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.400 g), and 2-MIM (3.380 g) for 1 h, which was then degassed under vacuum for 10 min to ensure that precursor solution entered all the voids of the template. The obtained precursor@PS was fully dried at 60 °C in air. Afterwards, precursor@PS was immersed in a mixture of ammonia/methanol (1:1 v/v) and then degassed under vacuum for 10 min to ensure that the mixed solution was homogeneously permeated. The template was left to stand in the mixed solution at room temperature to allow crystal nucleation and growth. After 24 h, Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF@PS was obtained, and it was washed several times with methanol and fully dried at 60 °C. Next, Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF@PS was washed 5 times with DMF to remove the PS template completely, and then washed with dichloromethane to remove DMF and fully dried at 60 °C to obtain 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF. 2.2.3 Preparation of 3DOM FeCo/NC 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF (0.15 g) was placed in a quartz boat and pyrolyzed in a tube furnace at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under Ar atmosphere, and kept at 900 °C for 2 h to obtain 3DOM FeCo/NC. 2.2.4 Preparation of 3DOM Fe/NC and 3DOM Co/NC The synthetic route is similar to that of the 3DOM FeCo/NC except without adding Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Fe(acac)3, respectively. 2.2.5 Preparation of C-FeCo/NC Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.312 g), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.568 g), and Fe(acac)3 (0.795 g) were dissolved in methanol (150 mL). Then 2-MIM (6.750 g) was dissolved in methanol (50 mL). The above two solutions were mixed vigorously under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 24 h. The products obtained were centrifuged and washed several times with methanol and dried overnight at 60 °C to obtain C-Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF. Finally, C-Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF (0.15 g) was placed in a quartz boat and pyrolyzed in a tube furnace under Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h to obtain C-FeCo/NC. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical experiments were performed at the electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E) at room temperature in the three-electrode system. Catalyst ink was prepared by mixing catalyst (2.5 mg), H2O (225 µL), ethanol (225 µL), and Nafion solution (50 µL), and sonicated for 1 h. The HER test was performed in 1.0 M KOH solution using an L-type glassy carbon electrode (GCE) as the working electrode (WE), a Hg/HgO electrode as the reference electrode (RE), and a graphite rod as the counter electrode (CE). The ink (10 µL) was uniformly loaded onto a freshly polished GCE (diameter = 3.0 mm) as a WE, loaded with 0.7 mg cm−2 catalyst. All potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to Eq. (1). (1) E ( vs. RHE ) = E ( vs. Hg/HgO) + 0.098 + 0.059 × pH Before the HER test, N2 was bubbled in solution for 30 min. The catalyst was then activated by potential cycling for 20 cycles at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 at from 0.024 to −0.676 V. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were recorded at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 with 90% iR compensation. The Tafel plots were extracted from the corresponding overpotential linear regions based on the logarithm of the current density, according to Eq. (2). (2) η = b log | j | + a where η, j, b, and a are the overpotential, current density, Tafel slope, and intercept, respectively. The double layer capacitance (C dl) was obtained using cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at different scan rates. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was obtained in the frequency range of 106–0.1 Hz with an amplitude voltage of 5 mV measured at open circuit voltage. The equivalent circuit model was fitted with self-built equivalent circuit model using Zview software. The durability of the catalysts was analyzed by the chronopotentiometry (CP) at a constant current density of 100 mA cm−2. Simultaneously, 5000 cycles were performed at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 and then the polarization curves were recorded. The ORR test was performed in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution using a rotation ring disk electrode (RRDE) as the WE, a Hg/HgO electrode as the RE, and a graphite rod as the CE. The ink (20 µL) was uniformly loaded onto a freshly polished RRDE (diameter = 5.6 mm) as a WE, loaded with 0.4 mg cm−2 catalyst. CV measurements were recorded at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 in the potential range of 0.1–1.3 V. LSV was measured by RRDE at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 at 1600 r min−1. The H2O2 yield (H2O2%) and electron transfer number (n) were calculated from Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) H 2 O 2 % = 200 × I R / N I D + I R / N (4) n = 4 × I D I D + I R / N where I D is the disc current, I R is the ring current, and N is the collection efficiency of the RRDE (0.37 in this work). The number of electrons transferred for the ORR is calculated from the K-L equation (Eqs. (5) and (6)). (5) 1 j = 1 j K + 1 j L = 1 j K + 1 B ω 1/2 (6) B = 0.2 nFC 0 D 0 2/3 V − 1/6 where j, j K, and j L are the measured current density, the kinetic current density, and diffusion-limiting current density, respectively. ω represents the angular velocity. C 0 is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.26 × 10−6 mol cm−3). D 0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M KOH (D 0 = 1.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1). n is the electron transfer number. F is the Faraday constant (F = 96,485 C mol−1). V is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte (V = 1.09 × 10−2 cm2 s−1 in 0.1 M KOH). 2.4 Zn-air battery test The electrocatalyst (5 mg), ethanol (450 μL), deionized water (DIW) (450 μL), and 5 wt% Nafion suspension (100 μL) were mixed and ultrasonicated for 1 h. The resulting ink was dropped on carbon fiber paper and dried in air. The average loading of the catalyst was 1 mg cm−2. Commercial Pt/C electrodes were prepared as described above under the same loading conditions. Zn-air batteries were assembled using the above electrode as the cathode, a piece of zinc foil as the anode, and a 6.0 M KOH solution containing 0.2 M Zn(OAc)2 as the electrolyte. Polarization curves (at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1) and constant current discharge and charge tests were measured using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of the catalyst Fig. 1 illustrates the fabrication procedure of 3DOM FeCo/NC. Evenly-arranged PS microsphere (diameter = 220 nm) array (Fig. 2 a) was used as template, and immersed in methanol solution containing Co2+, Zn2+, Fe(acac)3, and 2-MIM. These species can diffuse into voids of the PS template driven by capillary forces. Then, it was further immersed in an ammonia/methanol mixed solution for heterogeneous nucleation. Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF@PS was obtained by the dual-solvent induced heterogeneous nucleation method [34]. In this process, ammonia induced rapid crystallization, while methanol stabilized the precursor and regulated the relative velocity between nucleation and growth of ZnCo-ZIF [53]. Fe(acac)3 as guest molecule with diameter (d f = 9.8 Å) between the pores (d p = 3.4 Å) and cavities (d c = 11.6 Å) of ZnCo-ZIF hence can be doped into the host framework [54,55]. Afterwards, the PS template was removed by DMF, and the 3D porous skeleton of Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF was obtained. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) shows the 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF has a tetrakaidecahedron structure (Fig. 2b), similar to the typical morphology of ZnCo-ZIF. Macro-pores with average diameter of about 150 nm and interconnecting pores of about 50 nm are clearly observed (Fig. 2c). Close contact of adjacent PS spheres prevented the penetration of precursor into the connection points, and thus resulted in the interconnecting meso-pores. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) further reveals the numerous continuous pathways inside the 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF (Fig. 2d, e), which are conceivably in favor of mass transfer and fully exposure of active sites. The existence of Fe(acac)3 in this porous structure was demonstrated by ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectroscopy. The characteristic peaks of Fe(acac)3 at 280 and 353 nm were observed in the spectrum of 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF (Fig. S1). Doping Fe(acac)3 did not disrupt the crystallization of ZnCo-ZIF. As the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were shown in Fig. 2(f), 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF with Fe contents of 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, and 30% (corresponding to 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF-10, 15, 20, 25, and 30) were all well matched with 3DOM ZnCo-ZIF. Similar results were obtained for the XRD patterns of 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZIF-8 without Co and C-Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF without 3DOM structure (Figs. S2, S3). Whereas, the crystal face slightly changed as indicated by the gradual variation of relative diffraction intensity with the Fe increase. The target structure of 3DOM FeCo/NC was finally obtained by pyrolyzing 3DOM Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF under Ar atmosphere (If not specifically denoted, 3DOM FeCo/NC denotes a catalyst synthesized with 220 nm PS, pyrolyzed at 900 °C, with Fe accounting for 25% of the sum of Zn + Co atoms). SEM images show that 3DOM FeCo/NC retained the tetrakaidecahedron structure as well as macro-pores and interconnected pores (Fig. 3 a–c), but the macro-pores were shrank to 120–140 nm. The interconnecting meso-pores also collapse to a certain extent, with the pore size shrank from ∼50 to 40–45 nm. TEM images (Fig. 3d, e) clearly reveal that the polyhedral skeletal structure of 3DOM FeCo/NC is fully penetrating. NPs were observed to be uniformly distributed in the skeleton (Fig. 3f). They are CoFe2O4 and CoFe alloy generated by pyrolysis of Fe(acac)3@ZnCo-ZIF, which have been identified by XRD. As shown in Fig. 3(g), all 3DOM FeCo/NC with different Fe contents exhibit distinct diffraction peaks at 30.1°, 35.4°, 43.0°, 56.9°, and 62.7°, which are attributed to the (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes of CoFe2O4 (PDF#22-1086), respectively. Meanwhile, the diffraction peak at 44.7° corresponding to the (110) plane of CoFe (PDF#44-1433) was also observed. The XRD characterization results clearly demonstrated that a CoFe2O4 and CoFe bimorph heterostructure exists in the 3DOM FeCo/NC. The lattices of the NPs were clearly shown in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Fig. 3h, i). Lattice fringes with spacing of 2.51, 2.97, 1.62, and 1.49 Å are attributed to the (311), (220), (511), and (440) crystal planes of CoFe2O4, respectively, while the lattice spacing of 1.98 and 1.96 Å belongs to the (110) crystal plane of CoFe. The contents of Fe and Co in 3DOM FeCo/NC were 4.24 wt% and 2.21 wt% determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), respectively. Concurrently, the elemental mapping revealed by the high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images clearly demonstrates that the elements C, N, O, Co, and Fe are uniformly distributed in the catalyst (Fig. 3j). Similarly, 3DOM FeCo/NC-10, 15, 25, and 30 (with different Fe contents), 3DOM Co/NC (without Fe), and 3DOM Fe/NC (without Co) were also synthesized by the hard template method. The SEM images (Fig. S4) show that these catalysts all exhibited well-ordered 3D hierarchical porous structures. Moreover, the XRD pattern of 3DOM Fe/NC without Co (Fig. S5) shows characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 (PDF#88-0866). Meanwhile, a contrastive catalyst (C-FeCo/NC) was also synthesized by a routine method without using PS template. It presents a typical rhombic dodecahedral morphology with particle size of 200–250 nm, and exhibits no macro- or meso-pores (Fig. S6). Fig. 4 (a) shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of 3DOM FeCo/NC and C-FeCo/NC, which reflect their specific surface areas and corresponding pore size distributions. 3DOM FeCo/NC presents type II isotherm at low (P/P 0 = 0–0.1) and high (P/P 0 = 0.9–1.0) relative pressures. The dramatic increase at high relative pressure distinctively reflects the characteristic of macro-pores. At medium relative pressures (P/P 0 = 0.1–0.9), it presents type IV isotherm with typical H4-type hysteresis loop, demonstrating the presence of meso-pores. The type II + IV adsorption isotherm indicates the macro-meso-micro-porous construction of 3DOM FeCo/NC. By contrast, C-FeCo/NC shows type I + IV isotherm with a H4-type hysteresis loop, demonstrating that it is mainly composed of micro- and meso-pores [36,47]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (S BET) of 3DOM FeCo/NC is 797.508 m2 g−1, significantly higher than the 484.943 m2 g−1 of C-FeCo/NC. Although the particle size of C-FeCo/NC is only 200–250 nm, much smaller than that of 3DOM FeCo/NC (1–1.5 μm), the S BET is still lower. The results confirm that the 3D ordered macro-pores substantially enhanced the specific surface area. Pore size distribution of 3DOM FeCo/NC further reveals the presence of micro-pores at 0.5, 0.9, and 1.1 nm and meso-pores at 3.8 nm (Fig. 4b). The chemical state and elemental composition of 3DOM FeCo/NC were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). It confirmed the presence of C, N, O, Fe, and Co elements in 3DOM FeCo/NC (Fig. S7). The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Co 2p (Fig. 4c) indicates that 3DOM FeCo/NC contains Co2+ (2p 1/2: 799.5 eV, 2p 3/2: 787.5 eV), Co3+ (2p 1/2: 796.5 eV, 2p 3/2: 783.4 eV), and Co0 (2p 1/2: 795.1 eV, 2p 3/2: 780.8 eV). As compared to 3DOM Co/NC, the introducing of Fe decreased its electron binding energy due to the electron cloud shifting towards Co [56]. Meanwhile, Co mostly exists in the form of compound in 3DOM FeCo/NC since the proportion of Co0 peak area is significantly lower than that of 3DOM Co/NC. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p (Fig. 4d), Fe3+ (2p 1/2: 727.5 eV, 2p 3/2: 714.5 eV), Fe2+ (2p 1/2: 724.4 eV, 2p 3/2: 711.3 eV), and Fe0 (2p 1/2: 720.1 eV, 2p 3/2: 711.2 eV) were clearly identified in 3DOM FeCo/NC. Conversely, the characteristic peaks of Fe0 were not detected in 3DOM Fe/NC, thereby indicating that the Co doping resulted in the formation of the CoFe alloy phase. Just opposite the situation of Co, electron binding energy of Fe shifted to larger value compared to 3DOM Fe/NC due to the decrease of the electron cloud density. The electrons transfer between Fe and Co is beneficial for catalytic reaction. Furthermore, the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio of 3DOM FeCo/NC (3.5) is significantly higher than that of 3DOM Fe/NC (0.85), while the Co2+/Co3+ ratio of 3DOM FeCo/NC (1.17) also exceeds that of 3DOM Co/NC (0.31). These results demonstrate that the formation of the composite phase induces a notable alteration in the chemical state of the catalyst surface, leading to the partial reduction of metal sites. This observation further corroborates the electron transfer from CoFe to CoFe2O4, highlighting the enhanced electronic interactions within the composite structure. The characteristic peaks of N 1s at 405.1, 401.8, 400.9, and 398.6 eV (Fig. 4e) are attributed to the oxidized-N, graphitic-N, pyrrolic-N, and pyridinic-N in 3DOM FeCo/NC. Among them, graphitic-N and pyridinic-N are particularly favorable for HER and ORR. In addition, a characteristic peak at 399.7 eV, which corresponds to Fe/Co-N, was also observed, suggesting that the N atoms participate in the formation of catalytic microstructure. The abundant N species in 3DOM FeCo/NC can effectively contribute to the catalytic process. This is attributed to that the electronegativity of N is larger than that of C, which produces a polarization effect in the carbon network and enhances the spin density of the C atoms, thus facilitating the electron transfer and promoting the adsorption of oxygenated species [57]. Among the different N-doped structures, pyridinic-N modifies the band structure of carbon, increases the density of p states near the Fermi level, and lowers the work function. Graphitic-N reduces the electron density on the C nuclei, contributing to the transfer of electrons from the adjacent C to N, which back-donates to the adjacent C p z orbitals. Such a process of donation and backdonation promotes the dissociation of oxygenated species on adjacent C atoms, contributing to the formation of strong chemical bonds between C and O [58]. Fe/Co–N bonds are produced by the interaction of NPs of Fe and Co with N coordination on N-doped carbon. The local metal−N−C (M−N−C) bonds are contributing to the catalysis of HER and ORR. For HER, the structure of M−N−C provides more electrons to the O of adsorbed oxygenated species, forming more d-vacancy orbitals, stronger heterojunction of the metal with the O-2p orbitals, and enhanced interactions of M−N−C with water/hydroxyl groups, resulting in the enhanced kinetics of HER [59]. For ORR, the M−N−C electronic structure promotes O–O bond breaking and adsorption of related oxygen intermediates, thus facilitating reaction kinetics [8,60]. High-resolution spectrum of C 1s (Fig. 4f) demonstrates the presence of C=O, C–O, C–N, and C–C/C=C in 3DOM FeCo/NC, respectively. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performances of 3DOM FeCo/NC 3.2.1 HER performance The HER properties of 3DOM FeCo/NC were investigated in 1.0 M KOH. The LSV curves are shown in Fig. 5 (a), which present overpotentials of 96, 221, and 383 mV at current densities of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), 100 mA cm−2 (η 100), and 500 mA cm−2 (η 500), respectively (Fig. 5b). Although the HER property is inferior to commercial Pt/C at low current density, 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibits much better performance when current densities exceeds 235 mA cm−2. The η 500 of 3DOM FeCo/NC is remarkably lower than that of Pt/C (490 mV), demonstrating its superior HER performance. Meanwhile, the highest current density rise to nearly 900 mA cm−2 without needing load of 3DOM FeCo/NC on any conductive substrate. It indicated that the catalyst has superb electrical conductivity and advanced HER activity at large current densities. Compared to recently reported catalysts with similar elements and compositions, the HER performance of 3DOM FeCo/NC is superior to most similar catalysts (Table S1). Compared with 3DOM Co/NC and 3DOM Fe/NC with single metal loading, 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibited considerably higher HER activity at all current densities. 3DOM Co/NC was unable to reach 500 mA cm−2, while 3DOM Fe/NC even failed to reach 100 mA cm−2. Raman spectra (Fig. S8) reveal that the I D/I G of 3DOM FeCo/NC is 0.96, larger than that of 3DOM Fe/NC (0.72) and 3DOM Co/NC (0.92). It indicated that the co-doping of Fe and Co creates more defects in the N-doped carbon skeleton compared to the single metal doping, which is more conducive to the catalytic process. Therefore, it can be concluded that the synergistic effect of Fe and Co in the CoFe2O4 and CoFe sites is favorable to enhancing HER activity. C-FeCo/NC also showed better HER activity than 3DOM Co/NC and 3DOM Fe/NC, but was inferior to 3DOM FeCo/NC due to lack of hierarchical porous structures. The interconnected 3D ordered macro-pores dramatically enhanced mass transfer, and largely increased active site exposure within the catalyst. Both factors are conducive to the HER process. In the case of catalyst with different Fe contents, 3DOM FeCo/NC-25, atomic ratio accounting for 25% of the sum of Zn and Co, possesses the best HER activity. The overpotential is significantly lower than that of catalyst with Fe contents of 10, 15, 20, and 30 (Fig. S9a). The Tafel slope of 3DOM FeCo/NC (99.5 mV dec−1) is lower than that of 3DOM Co/NC (112.9 mV dec−1), 3DOM Fe/NC (181.0 mV dec−1), and C-FeCo/NC (107.6 mV dec−1) (Fig. 5c), validating the superior HER kinetics compared to the catalysts with single metal loading and without 3DOM structure. Consistent with the LSV results, 3DOM FeCo/NC-25 also exhibits the lowest Tafel slope compared to other catalysts with different Fe contents (Fig. S9b). EIS confirms that 3DOM Co/NC has the lowest charge transfer resistance (R ct) among the comparative catalysts. As the Nyquist plots were shown in Fig. 5(d), 3DOM-FeCo/NC presents a smaller half circle than 3DOM Co/NC, 3DOM Fe/NC, and C-FeCo/NC. It is also the smallest in the catalysts with different Fe contents (Fig. S9c). The R ct between the electrolyte and 3DOM-FeCo/NC is only 2.12 Ω as calculated by fitting the EIS to the equivalent circuit model (Fig. 5d). The value is significantly lower than the other catalysts, further confirming that FeCo bimetallic synergistic interaction results in higher electron transfer efficiency. Together with the 3D ordered macro-pores, it ensured the charge transport competence and promoted the exceptional HER kinetics. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the catalyst was estimated by C dl (Fig. S10), which was obtained through CV curves in the non-Faraday region at different scan rates (Figs. S11–S15). As compared to other catalysts, 3DOM FeCo/NC showed the largest C dl value (79.4 mF cm−2), demonstrating its maximum ECSA value which is favorable for HER. The catalytic stability of 3DOM FeCo/NC was further examined. After 5000 cycles of CV in the HER range, the LSV curves changed quite slightly, and the overpotential was almost comparable to that before cyclic test (Fig. 5e). η 100 increased by only 7 mV and η 500 by only 15 mV. Meanwhile, the HER stability of 3DOM FeCo/NC at high current densities was further measured by CP (Fig. 5f). At a current density of 100 mA cm−2, the overpotential could remain stable for 100 h, and the potential can still be maintained at about 95% of the original value. The morphology, elemental, and phase structure of 3DOM FeCo/NC before and after HER were evaluated to further demonstrate the stability of the catalyst. SEM image (Fig. S16) shows that the morphology of 3DOM FeCo/NC did not significantly change after the stability test. XRD pattern of 3DOM FeCo after HER showed that the characteristic peaks of CoFe and CoFe2O4 remained evident (Fig. S17). Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) elemental analysis revealed that the elemental compositions and contents of 3DOM FeCo/NC were almost unchanged before and after HER catalysis (Fig. S18 and Tables S2, S3). Elemental analysis was also performed by ICP-OES, and the results showed that there was no significant change in the Fe and Co content of the catalyst after the HER stability test (Table S4). It demonstrated the stability of the HER catalytic process of 3DOM FeCo/NC. 3.2.2 ORR performance The ORR electrocatalytic properties of the as-synthesized catalysts were explored by the RRDE technique in 0.1 M KOH. All catalysts showed a distinct ORR cathodic reduction peak in the CV curves that were recorded in O2-saturated solution (Fig. S19), attesting that they possess the activity in the ORR process. In the LSV polarization curves collected at 1600 r min−1 (Fig. 6 a), the half-wave potentials (E 1/2 = 0.896 V) and onset potentials (E onset = 1.025 V) of 3DOM FeCo/NC are significantly higher than those of 3DOM Fe/NC (E onset = 0.973 V, E 1/2 = 0.866 V), 3DOM Co/NC (E onset = 0.903 V, E1/2 = 0.835 V), and C-FeCo/NC (E onset = 0.964 V, E 1/2 = 0.857 V), also superior to that of commercial Pt/C (E onset = 0.955 V, E 1/2 = 0.842 V) (Fig. 6b). The effect of Fe content on ORR was disclosed by the LSV polarization curves (Fig. S20). 3DOM FeCo/NC-25 with Fe contents of 25% exhibited the most optimal ORR performance than the other Fe-doped catalysts in the case of high E onset and E 1/2. Accordingly, 3DOM FeCo/NC-25 was selected as the principal subject in the subsequent ORR test. The obtained results visually demonstrated that bimetallic synergism of CoFe2O4 and CoFe alloying sites considerably enhanced the ORR catalytic activity. Meanwhile, the interconnected 3DOM structure substantially improved mass transfer as well as exposure of active sites in the ORR process. It is in favor of facile transport of O2 and OH− species inside the catalyst, confirming that the morphology modulation is beneficial for ORR catalysis. Furthermore, Tafel slopes (Fig. 6c) were obtained from the transformation of LSV polarization curves to evaluate the ORR kinetics of the catalysts. 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibited the smallest Tafel slope of 71.4 mV dec−1, showing the optimum ORR kinetic and intrinsic catalytic activity. In the Nyquist plot (Fig. S21), 3DOM FeCo/NC also presents the smallest semicircle, proving its lowest R ct. A comparison of E onset and E 1/2 with previous literatures (Fig. 6d and Table S5) reveals that the ORR performance of 3DOM FeCo/NC is superior to majority of similar Fe-, Co-, and FeCo-based catalysts reported in recent years. To investigate the catalytic selectivity of 3DOM FeCo/NC, LSV curves were recorded at different rotational speeds, and Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots were obtained from current densities at different potentials (Fig. S22). The electron transfer number (n) was calculated to be approximately 3.93 according to the K-L equation, attesting that the ORR-catalyzed reaction is selective with nearly four-electron transfer. The ORR catalytic pathways were evaluated by ring current and disk current measured by RRDE. 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibited the lowest H2O2 yield, which remained less than 5% in the potential range of 0.2–0.8 V (Fig. 6e). The highest electron transfer number (3.90–3.99) was observed in the corresponding potential interval, further verifying that the four-electron transfer process dominated the catalytic reaction. Cyclic stability and durability of catalysts are essential for practical applications. After 5000 and 10,000 CV cycles, the E 1/2 of 3DOM FeCo/NC decreased by only 2 and 6 mV, whereas the benchmark commercial Pt/C underwent decrease of 21 mV after 5000 CV cycles (Fig. 6f). Simultaneously, chronoamperometry test (Fig. 6g) was performed to further evaluate the durability. After 20 h of ORR, it still retained 98% of the initial current. In contrast, Pt/C decreased to 76% of the initial current after only 12 h. The morphology, elemental, and phase structure of 3DOM FeCo before and after ORR were also evaluated. The SEM image (Fig. S23), XRD plots (Fig. S17), EDS elemental analysis (Fig. S24 and Table S6), and ICP-OES (Table S4) sufficiently demonstrated the stability of 3DOM FeCo/NC in the ORR catalytic process. 3DOM FeCo/NC also showed good tolerance for methanol as indicated by chronoamperometry test (Fig. S25). The current density of 3DOM FeCo/NC scarcely decayed after addition of methanol at 100 s, whereas it drastically decayed about 70% for Pt/C. The results suggested the exceptional methanol tolerance of 3DOM FeCo/NC. The OER performance of 3DOM FeCo/NC was also measured in 1.0 M KOH solution. As shown in Fig. S26(a), the overpotential of 3DOM FeCo/NC for OER is 318 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is quite similar to that of the commercial benchmark IrO2 (η 10 = 315 mV). In a similar manner to the activity trend of HER and ORR, 3DOM FeCo/NC is also significantly superior to that of 3DOM Fe/NC (η 10 = 446 mV), 3DOM Co/NC (η 10 = 383 mV), and C-FeCo/NC (η 10 = 358 mV) in OER. Meanwhile, the Tafel slope of 3DOM FeCo/NC (68.4 mV dec−1) is conspicuously lower than that of 3DOM Fe/NC (202.1 mV dec−1), 3DOM Co/NC (138.9 mV dec−1), C-FeCo/NC (91.2 mV dec−1), and IrO2 (85.6 mV dec−1) (Fig. S26b), meaning that the 3DOM FeCo/NC catalyst has a much faster kinetic process in OER. The superior ORR, OER, and HER catalytic activity of 3DOM FeCo/NC originates from the well-controlled mass transfer capability of the interconnecting macro-porous structure and the unique synergistic effect between CoFe2O4 and CoFe. Firstly, the distinctive 3DOM structure gives rise to periodic absorption potential valleys within the catalyst, which consistently directs reactant molecules and ions towards the catalyst surface. This effectively generates a concentrated microenvironment, significantly enhancing the reaction kinetics. In comparison, the irregular microelectric distribution within an unordered electric field induces random reactant fluxes, resulting in a mismatch between the supply-demand of catalyst and reactants [41]. The effect on the bandgap before and after the formation of the heterostructure was investigated by UV-vis spectroscopy. The bandgap energies of 3DOM FeCo/NC with CoFe/CoFe2O4 heterostructure and 3DOM Fe/NC with only Fe3O4 were calculated by Tauc equation (αhν)2 = A (hν − E g) [61]. Two bandgap energy values were obtained by extrapolating the linear part of the above equation (Fig. S27). The two bandgap values correspond to the two pathways for the electrons of CoFe/CoFe2O4 from the O-2p orbital energy levels in the valence band (VB) to the low-spin M3+ and high-spin M2+ conduction bands (CB), respectively [62,63]. As demonstrated by the Tauc plot, the bandgap of the 3DOM FeCo/NC heterostructure is effectively reduced by the doping of Co to form the CoFe/CoFe2O4 (3DOM FeCo/NC) structure, in comparison to the Co-free Fe3O4 (3DOM Fe/NC) structure. The bandgap energies of 3DOM FeCo/NC (0.83 and 1.24 eV) are significantly lower than those of 3DOM Fe/NC (1.33 and 2.18 eV). It demonstrates that the formation of heterogeneous structures enhances electron transfer, thus promoting the catalytic activity of HER and ORR. Further investigation of the electronic structure of the CoFe/CoFe2O4 heterojunction through solid-state physics theory can provide in-depth insights into the mechanism of the ORR and HER activities of 3DOM FeCo/NC. The electronic configuration of alloy and semiconductor heterostructures can be explained by reference to the Mott-Schottky rule (Fig. S28). The work function (Φ M) of the CoFe alloy is 4.75 eV, which is smaller than the work function (Φ S) of CoFe2O4 of 5.81 eV, satisfying the requirements for the constitution of a Mott-Schottky barrier [28,64,65]. In this case, the charge at the CoFe/CoFe2O4 interface is redistributed, resulting in the formation of a strongly coupled heterogeneous interface between the CoFe and CoFe2O4 phases. Consequently, the valence and conduction bands of CoFe2O4 bend, thereby forming a Mott-Schottky contact between CoFe2O4 and CoFe. The electrons can be spontaneously transferred from the CoFe alloy side across the heterogeneous interface to the CoFe2O4 side [66,67]. Such a unidirectional electron transfer composition makes the hole-rich CoFe alloy electrophilic and the electron-rich CoFe2O4 nucleophilic, which leads to a local reconfiguration of the electron cloud density [61]. It contributes to the promotion of the adsorption behavior of oxygenated species, the optimization of reaction pathways, and the lowering of energy barriers during the HER and ORR catalytic processes, thus enhancing the HER and ORR activities. 3.3 Effect of pyrolysis temperatures on catalysts Pyrolysis temperature affects the morphology and performance of catalyst. TEM images of catalysts derived from 800 °C (3DOM FeCo/NC-800) and 1000 °C (3DOM FeCo/NC-1000) are shown in Fig. S29. Along with the fine Fe, Co-containing NPs, a few large Zn NPs were also observed on the skeleton of 3DOM FeCo/NC-800. It is attributed to the fact that 800 °C is not reach the boiling point of Zn (907 °C). Zn did not completely evaporate and was partially retained in the porous skeleton. In the case of 3DOM FeCo/NC-1000, all the NPs presented in large size. The calcination temperature is too high to generate fine NPs; aggregation of FeCo elements is inevitable which caused the formation of large size NPs. Different micromorphology results in divergent electrocatalytic properties. The LSV polarization curves (Fig. S30a) show that 3DOM FeCo/NC-900 has superior HER activity at low and medium current densities (<505 mA cm−2), while 3DOM FeCo/NC-1000 exhibits better performance at higher current densities. HER activity of 3DOM FeCo/NC-800 is considerably weak due to the existence of Zn NPs in the carbon skeleton. They are not HER-active sites and in verse hinder the HER catalytic process. The corresponding Tafel plots (Fig. S30b) revealed that 3DOM FeCo/NC-900 possesses the most rapid HER kinetics, of which the Tafel slope (99.5 mV dec−1) is lower than that of 3DOM FeCo/NC-1000 (108.4 mV dec−1) and 3DOM FeCo/NC-800 (255.4 mV dec−1). 3DOM FeCo/NC-900 also exhibited smaller semicircle than the other two catalysts in the Nyquist plots (Fig. S30c), indicating its lowest R ct value. Subsequently, the ORR performance of the catalysts obtained at 800, 900, and 1000 °C was inquired. 3DOM FeCo/NC-900 shows the best ORR performance as it presents the most positive cathodic reduction peak in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. S31a), the highest E onset and E 1/2 (Fig. S31b), and the lowest Tafel slope (Fig. S31c). According to the excellent catalytic activity for HER and ORR, it can be concluded that 900 °C is the most optimal pyrolysis temperature for constructing 3DOM FeCo/NC catalyst. At this temperature, majority of Zn volatilize; meanwhile, it does not cause FeCo phases to excessively agglomerate and thus allows the active sites to be fully utilized. 3.4 Effect of macro-pore size on catalysts Catalytic properties of 3DOM FeCo/NC with different large-pore sizes were further studied. The pores were adjusted by the size of PS microspheres (170, 220, 375, and 500 nm) composing the templates. The LSV curves of HER (Fig. S32a) demonstrated that the overpotential gradually decreased with the reduction of PS size from 500 to 220 nm, but the value substantially increased by further reducing PS to 170 nm. The ORR performance also showed a similar trend to pore size variation (Fig. S32b). The catalysts obtained by PS with 220 and 375 nm exhibited obviously higher E onset and E 1/2 than that obtained using 500 and 170 nm PS as templates. The results indicate that the macro-pore size of 3DOM FeCo/NC has a significant impact on the electrocatalytic activity. SEM images (Fig. S33) disclosed the pore structure of the catalysts. Small PS (170 nm) resulted in only surface-level macro-pores, absence of interconnecting meso-pores. The inconsecutive macro-pore is not conducive for mass transfer, so that the internal active sites are not accessible by electrolyte, and the catalytic activity of 3DOM FeCo/NC-170 is unsatisfactory. For the PS size of 220 nm, there are overlapping parts between the PS spheres. Interconnecting pores presented between the macro-pores after PS removal, which enabled the internal macro-pores to be easily accessed by electrolyte, thereby facilitating catalytic reaction. With PS size further increasing, macro-pores occupied the majority of the space within 3DOM FeCo/NC-500, and the sizes of the interconnecting pores also increased. Whereas, it should be noticed that the void space among the PS array is also enlarged regardless of the stacking type. As a consequence, the derived skeleton obviously became thick, and the interior active sites of porous skeleton were once difficult to access through the intrinsic micro-pores. Although the structure is more favorable for mass transfer, the catalytic performance is inferior to 3DOM FeCo/NC-220. Consequently, the formation of excessively large macro-pores is detrimental to the efficacy of catalysis, so appropriate pore size is required to achieve ideal results. 3.5 Zn-air battery performance Based on the appreciable ORR property of 3DOM FeCo/NC, a Zn-air battery was assembled for evaluating its practical applicability (Fig. 7 a). The battery is composed of 3DOM FeCo/NC as the air cathode, polished zinc foil as the anode, and 6.0 M KOH + 0.2 M zinc acetate solution as the electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the open-circuit voltage (OCV) of the Zn-air battery is 1.482 V, higher than that of the benchmark using Pt/C + IrO2 as cathode (1.447 V). The discharge polarization curves and the corresponding power density curves show that 3DOM FeCo/NC delivers a maximum power density of 163 mW cm−2 at 255 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7c). It is noticeably higher than 137 mW cm−2 that was attained by the Pt/C + IrO2 battery at 199 mA cm−2. In order to examine the rate performance and stability of 3DOM FeCo/NC battery, constant-current multistep discharge tests were performed (Fig. 7d). The 3DOM FeCo/NC battery exhibited a fast response upon current change, while the discharge voltage maintains stable at specific current densities. Meanwhile, when the current density returned from 10 to 1 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage of 3DOM FeCo/NC quickly recovered to the initial value without obvious decay, whereas the Pt/C + IrO2 battery suffered from a distinct voltage drop. It demonstrated that the 3DOM FeCo/NC battery possesses a higher discharge steady state and quicker response than the Pt/C + IrO2 battery [68,69]. Furthermore, continuous discharge was conducted at 5 mA cm−2 for the two batteries. 3DOM FeCo/NC remains a longer discharge time at a higher voltage plateau compared to Pt/C + IrO2 (Fig. 7e). The specific capacity of the 3DOM FeCo/NC battery is calculated to be 815 mAh g−1 Zn with reference to the consumed mass of Zn foil, also higher than that of the Pt/C + IrO2 battery of 787 mAh g−1 Zn. Finally, long-term cycling capability of the 3DOM FeCo/NC battery was evaluated by repeated charging and discharging at 2 mA cm−2 with cycle duration of 30 min. The 3DOM FeCo/NC battery maintained stable cyclic charging and discharging over 100 h with a voltage gap of only about 0.65 V and a round-trip efficiency of 69% (Fig. 7f). The performance is much better than the benchmark Pt/C + IrO2 battery, which exhibited a voltage gap of 0.8 V and a round-trip efficiency of only 59%. Two connected 3DOM FeCo/NC batteries could light up a 2 V light emitting diode (LED) light bead (Fig. 7g), and one could easily drive a small fan (Fig. 7h). The above results indicate the great potential of 3DOM FeCo/NC for practical applications. 4 Conclusions In this study, we demonstrate the rational design and synthesis of a hierarchically porous Fe-Co bimetallic catalyst (3DOM FeCo/NC) with 3DOM architecture, exhibiting exceptional bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for both HER and ORR. The unique 3D-ordered interconnected macro-porous framework substantially enhances specific surface area while optimizing mass transport pathways, thus enabling full accessibility to embedded active sites within the carbon matrix. Strategic integration of Fe-Co dual metal centers creates synergistic electronic interactions that effectively mitigate kinetic limitations in cathodic reactions, as evidenced by remarkably low overpotentials of 221 and 383 mV at current densities of 100 and 500 mA cm−2 for HER performance metrics surpassing those of commercial Pt/C at high-current operations. The ORR characteristics further confirm superior catalytic efficacy, demonstrating an E onset of 1.025 V and a E 1/2 of 0.896 V. When implemented in Zn-air battery prototypes, the 3DOM FeCo/NC cathode achieves a peak power density of 163 mW cm−2 and specific capacity of 815 mAh g−1 Zn, outperforming conventional Pt/C + IrO2 hybrids while maintaining exceptional cycling stability over prolonged charge/discharge operations. This work establishes a groundbreaking methodology for engineering multifunctional electrocatalysts through hierarchical porosity engineering and bimetallic synergy manipulation, paving the way for next-generation energy conversion and storage technologies. coredata.dc:description: Optimizing active sites and enhancing mass transfer capability are of paramount importance for the improvement of electrocatalyst activity. On this basis, CoFe2O4/CoFe nanoparticles (NPs) loaded N-doped carbon (NC) that featured with interconnected three-dimensional (3D) ordered porous hierarchies (3DOM FeCo/NC) are prepared, and its electrocatalytic activity is studied. Due to the open structure of 3D ordered macro-pores that greatly improves the mass transfer capacity of the catalytic process and enhances the utilization of active sites inside the catalyst, as well as the uniform distribution of Fe and Co bimetallic sites on the porous skeleton, 3DOM FeCo/NC exhibits superior bi-functional catalytic activities for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The overpotential of HER is lower than that of commercial Pt/C when performed at high current density (>235 mA cm−2) in 1.0 M KOH, and the half-wave potential (0.896 V) of ORR in 0.1 M KOH is also superior to that of 20% commercial Pt/C and most other similar catalysts. The effective utilization and synergistic effect of CoFe2O4 and CoFe hetero-metallic sites remarkably enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, 3DOM FeCo/NC is assembled as an air electrode in Zn-air battery, and exhibits satisfactory maximum power density, open-circuit voltage, and charge/discharge stability over benchmark Pt/C + IrO2. This work contributes new insights into the design of transition-metal-based multifunctional catalysts, and has great potential for energy conversion and storage.
